author: potuz
content: It's just the way polynomial commitments work, we all agree in a bunch of points to where we will be evaluating our polynomials. And then we can commit to the value of that polynomial on other points without revealing the polynomial.

author: kevaundray
content: I think his question was about why we need to use the KZG polynomial commitment scheme, because in zcash they use a different polynomial commitment scheme which does not need a trusted setup

author: potuz
content: > Is not possible to extend this to kzg commitments?

author: potuz
content: That looks pretty much like asking if a trusted setup can be avoided in KZG

author: kevaundray
content: KZG uses a SRS whereas the scheme that zcash uses only needs a CRS

author: kevaundray
content: You would need a different polynomial commitment scheme, though they have different tradeoffs. I haven't looked at DAS to see exactly why we need KZG though, maybe it can be avoided or maybe there is an additional property apart from homomorphism that is assumed

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Vitalik wrote about potentially using inner product arguments (IPAs) instead of KZG commitments here: https://ethresear.ch/t/what-would-it-take-to-do-das-with-inner-product-arguments-ipas/12088

author: albusdompeldorius
content: IPAs, which is what Halo in zcash uses, does not rely on a trusted setup.
